Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network, SusChEM: Collaborative Electron-lattice Dynamics at an Atomically Controlled Buried Interface
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Abstract

An international collaborative research program bringing together scientists from Germany (Marburg University), Japan (National Institute for Materials Science) and the USA (Universities of Pittsburgh and Florida) will investigate the correlation between the structural and dynamical properties of GaP/Si buried interfaces in order to enable the fundamental understanding and practical applications of such materials. The GaP/Si interface is a material with potential applications having a high sustainability impact for high efficiency solar cells and silicon optoelectronics. Buried interfaces, excited states, and interaction of light with nonequilibrium charge distributions represent challenges at the forefront of condensed matter physics experiment and theory. By combining expertise in materials growth, structure characterization, ultrafast electronic and phonon spectroscopy, and theory, our team will investigate the relationship between the structural and ultrafast optoelectronic properties of GaP/Si interfaces. The optical and charge transport properties at an interface between two electronic materials depend on the band alignment between them, and the atomic scale structure of the interface in subtle ways that are difficult to characterize by experiment an theory. We will employ coherent phonon spectroscopy to investigate the ultrafast response of the interfacial electronic and lattice subsystems to band gap excitation. We expect that the interfacial carrier distributions and the built-in electric fields will substantially influence the coupled carrier-lattice dynamics. By comparison with the dynamics of the component materials (single crystal Si and GaP, we will identify the components of the ultrafast response that can be attributed to the existence of the interface. The interface response will be investigated for materials grown under different conditions that influence the material composition and crystalline structure on the atomic to the nanometer scales. From the spectroscopic measurements and theoretical simulations we will identify how the material structure affects the optical and electronic properties of GaP/Si interface. The tight integration of material growth and analysis, with ultrafast spectroscopic measurements will enable GaP/Si material optimization for practical applications. The experimental methodology will be applicable to studies of a broad range of interfacial phenomena of technologically important electronic materials.

Non-technical Abstract

Optimized electronic materials enable efficient generation and utilization of energy for continued economic development. The GaP/Si interface has the potential for applications in high efficiency solar cells for solar-to-electrical energy conversion, as well as for enabling optical signal processing within Si based electronic devices. The function of such composite materials, however, depends on the interface between them. Even though the dimensions of the crystalline lattices of GaP and Si are nearly identical, enabling growth of nearly defect free GaP overlayers on Si, their disparate ionic and covalent characters cause the electronic properties at the interface to change abruptly. Therefore, the optical and electronic properties of the composite materials strongly depend on the atomic scale structure and composition of the interface. Studying the relationship between the structure and electronic properties of interfaces is extremely difficult because it requires the ability to grow materials with particular characteristics, to correlate the atomic structure with the growth parameters, to characterize the relationship between the structure and electronic properties, as well as to develop a theoretical model for the interface that can close the feedback between the structural and functional investigations. We have constituted a collaborative team involving scientists from Germany (Marburg University), Japan (National Institute for Materials Science) and the USA (Universities of Pittsburgh and Florida) that will study the structure-function relationship of the GaP/Si interface based on specific materials growth, structure characterization by electron microscopy, investigation of the interface-specific electronic structure and optical response, as well as theory. The methodology and understanding obtained through the proposed study will be applicable to similar studies of a broad range of interfaces between electronic materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This was an international collaboration of experimental and theoretical research in condensed matter physics, with aim of characterizing  GaP/Si interfaces by non-invasive ultrafast optical spectroscopy. GaP/Si based devices have  optical and electronic applications such as high efficiency solar cells.  The PI Hrvoje Petek (Pitt) and co-PI Christopher J. Stanton (Univ. of Florida) collaborated with German and Japanese partners, headed by Prof. Ulrich Höfer (Marburg Univ.), and Dr. Kunie Ishioka [National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS)].

This project contributed to the development of human resources:

  1. Mr. Evan Thatcher, Ph.D. December 2015, UF.  Currently on the Faculty at Pacific Univ. in Oregon.
  2. Mr. Avinash Rustagi, Ph.D. May 2016, UF.  Currently a Postdoc at NC State Univ.
  3. Dr. Gary D. Sanders, Research Associate, UF.
  4. Ms. Shengmin Zhang, Ph.D. April 2017, Pitt. Currently employed by Mellon Bank.
  5. Ms. Jihang Zhu, Undergraduate Intern, Pitt. Currently a graduate student at Univ. of Texas.
  6. Mr. Karan Kapoor, Ph.D. Student, Pitt.

Graduate, undergraduate students and research associates were trained in forefront research topics in theoretical and experimental ultrafast optics, electronic structure, carrier and phonon ultrafast laser spectroscopy.  Their training has enhanced our future workforce in a high technology.

Highlights:

1. Ultrafast coupling of coherent phonons with nonequilibrium electron-hole plasmas.

When an ultrafast, femtosecond laser pulse shines on a semiconductor, it triggers vibrations of the solid known as coherent phonons.   We employed different laser colors to excite coherent phonons in GaAs and GaP. Under 400 nm illumination, electrons and holes are photoexcited further from equilibrium then with 800 nm light Our studies revealed distinct phases of the carrier-lattice dynamics including time-dependent screening, carrier-carrier and carrier-lattice thermalization, as well as carrier diffusion.The time evolution of  coherent phonon oscillations reports directly on the ultrafast quasiparticle correlations in the process of equilibration, as shown in Fig. 1. 

2.  Coherent phonon spectroscopy instrumentation development.

A new coherent phonon spectrometer was constructed in Petek’s laboratory. This instrument allows tunable femtosecond pump and probe experiments to be performed between the previously available 400 and 800 nm. This allows one to tune the excitation to specific optical resonances between electronic states of materials, and to measure their optical responses. The instrument and schematic are shown in Fig. 2, including the new results that show the utility of tunable laser excitation in that the efficiency of the optical phonon generation abruptly drops when it is tuned to 680 nm corresponding to threshold for the excitation from the split-off valence band to the conduction band.

3.   All-optical Evaluation of Electronic States at Buried GaP/Si(001) Interfaces.

The  goal of the NSF-MWN collaboration was the optical characterization of the interfaces of GaP films grown on Si. GaP films on Si can enhance the efficiency of Si solar cells.  We investigated  three different GaP/Si samples, and found that the amplitude of the coherent optical phonon signal depended strongly on the internal electric field created by the structure of the buried interface but is difficult to detect (Fig. 3). The strength of the phonon excitation signal depended critically on the presence of Anti-Phase Domains (APDs; places were Ga bonds to Ga instead of P).  Samples with  most APDs had strongest internal electric fields leading to stronger coherent optical phonon excitation. The international collaboration benefitted from ability of the team to produce functional devices with GaP films, characterize their APDs by atom-resolved microscopy, measure their phonon responses, and relate all the results by theory. This provided invaluable information on the relationship between the interface formation and its optical and electronic properties.

4. Acoustic  phonons in the indirect band gap semiconductors Si and GaP.

The  short absorption length of the 400 nm laser enabled generation of coherent acoustic phonons in addition to  optic ones.  Coherent acoustic phonons are like sound waves which are generated near the surface, and like ultrasound, provide information about the sample.  We studied the intrinsic generation and detection of coherent acoustic phonons in bulk Si and GaP, and used them to characterize structural and mechanical properties.. Collaboration between experiment and theory showed that the magnitude and phase of the coherent acoustic phonons provides information on microscopic interactions ( Fig. 4.)

5.  Sub-picosecond acoustic pulses at buried GaP/Si interfaces

We studied the optical generation and detection of ultrashort acoustic phonon pulses that propagate into three-dimensional semiconductor crystals. We demonstrated that excitation of GaP/Si(001) with femtosecond laser pulses excites ultrashort acoustic pulses at the sample heterointerface, which are directly observed as sharp spikes in the transient re?ectivity, seen in Fig, 5. The acoustic pulses are generated with the few atom thick intermixing layers of the GaP/Si interfaces. Our results show our optical pump-probe scheme enables one to nondestructively evaluate the structural quality of a buried semiconductor heterointerface on the nanometer scale.
